security_audit.summary: This is a documentation-only skill containing TypeScript coding guidelines. No executable code, network calls, or file system access. Purely educational content with no security risks.

content.value_statement: Stop code quality issues before they reach production. This skill provides comprehensive TypeScript guidelines including strict mode enforcement, type safety patterns, and anti-pattern detection.
actual_capabilities: Provides component and hook structure guidelines
limitations: Requires manual review for complex type issues

use_cases.title: Maintain Code Consistency

use_cases.title: Automated Quality Checks

use_cases.title: Learn TypeScript Best Practices
use_cases.description: Get guidance on proper TypeScript patterns and avoid common mistakes.

prompt_templates.title: Strict Mode Migration

best_practices: Always enable strict mode in tsconfig.json for maximum type safety
Use explicit return types on all exported functions for better API documentation
Replace 'any' with 'unknown' and implement proper type guards
anti_patterns: Using @ts-ignore to suppress errors instead of fixing the underlying issue
Type assertions to escape the type system: 'data as any'
Implicit any types in function parameters

faq.question: Which TypeScript projects are compatible?
faq.answer: Works with any TypeScript or React TypeScript project using strict mode configuration.

faq.question: Can it fix all TypeScript errors automatically?
faq.answer: It can identify and suggest fixes for most common errors, but complex type issues may need manual review.

faq.question: How does it integrate with existing linting tools?
faq.answer: Complements ESLint and Prettier by providing additional TypeScript-specific quality checks and patterns.

faq.question: Is my code data safe when using this skill?
faq.answer: Yes, this is a documentation-only skill that provides guidelines without accessing or storing your code.

faq.question: What if the suggested fix doesn't work?
faq.answer: Each suggestion includes multiple alternative approaches and links to TypeScript documentation.

faq.question: How is this different from TypeScript compiler errors?
faq.answer: It goes beyond compiler errors to enforce best practices, patterns, and team consistency standards.
